text:
Columbus Circle, north side, at the intersection of Broadway and Central Park West. Shown in the background is Broadway, west side, north from but not including West 59th Street, at Columbus Circle. Subway excavation is shown in the foreground.

About 1900.

William B. Parsons Collection.
title: Manhattan: Broadway - Central Park West

text:
Columbus Circle, north side, at the intersection of Broadway and Central Park West. The view shows work in progress for the I.R.T. Subway.

About 1901.

William B. Parsons Collection.
title: Manhattan: Broadway - Central Park West

text:
Seventh Avenue, adjoining and at the S. W. corner of Central Park South (W. 59th St.J, showing pavement condition relative to subway construction here. To the left are buildings occupied by the Central Park Riding Academy. The Seventh Avenue entrance to Central Park is at the right. Note the crosstown street car on Central Park South. This thoroughfare is actually W. 59th Street, changing it's name
where it borders the Park.
June 4, 1915.
Borough President of Manhattan
No. 668
title: Manhattan: 7th Avenue - Central Park South

text:
Seventh Avenue, at the south east corner of Central Park South (W. 59th Street). To the right is a portion of the Madrid, a unit of the Central Park Apartments. This structure was replaced in 1928 by the present New York Athletic Club. To the left is the Seventh Avenue entrance to the southerly portion of Central Park.

June 4, 1915.

Borough President of Manhattan
No. 677
title: Manhattan: 7th Avenue - Central Park South

title: Manhattan: 7th Avenue - Central Park South

text:
7th Avenue, at the south west corner of Central Park South. To the left background is the 7th Avenue entrance to the Park.

June 4, 1915

Borough President of Manhattan
No. 669
title: Manhattan: 7th Avenue - Central Park South

text:
Central Park West and Broadway north from 59th Street. The building in the immediate foreground, with the "Prince Albert" sign, is the American Circle Building. The next building north of it from 61st to 62nd Streets is the Mayflower Hotel, and beyond the Mayflower is the Century Theatre, demolished in 1930 for the erection of the Century Apartments. The picture gives a good view of construction work on the Eighth Avenue subway.

1927.

Ewing Galloway.
title: Manhattan: Central Park West - Broadway

text:
1 & 2

Central Park West (right) and Broadway (left), north from Columbus Circle (W. 59th St.), showing buildings to the west of Central Park. The latter is at the right and the entrance to same partially shown. Note the Maine Monument there. The triangular two-story structure in the center is the American Circle Building. This divides the thoroughfares and stands on the former site of the old Baltimore & Ohio Railroad Station. To the rear of same is W. 60th Street. North of this and facing the Park is the Mayflower Hotel (erected 1921). The twin-towered Century Apartments shown in view 2, replaced the old Century Theatre, a portion of which appears in the earlier photo. Geographically, Central Park West, is Eighth Avenue, an identity it resumes, south of this point, and north of 110th Street.

P. L. Sperr

March 11, 1929
March 19, 1938
title: Manhattan: Central Park West - Broadway

text:
1 & 2

This divides the thoroughfares and stands on the former site of the old Baltimore & Ohio Railroad Station. To the rear of same is W. 60th Street. North of this and facing the Park is the Mayflower Hotel (erected 1921). The twin-towered Century Apartments shown in view 2, replaced the old Century Theatre, a portion of which appears in the earlier photo. Geographically, Central Park West, is Eighth Avenue, an identity it resumes, south of this point, and north of 110th Street.

P. L. Sperr

title: Manhattan: Central Park West - Broadway

text:
Seventh Avenue at 59th Street, (Central Park South), showing
south end of Central Park.
June 28, 1931.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.
title: Manhattan: 7th Avenue - Central Park South
